row.Title: Octogon House off of old Rte. 2, general view, East Templeton, Massachusetts.
row.Creator: Floyd, Margaret Henderson.
row.Description: The Octagon house, also known as the T. T. Greenwood-Orre house, was built in 1855. A three story structure with a large cupola and four square rooms on each floor. Located on Main Street, near Cottage Lane in East Templeton Massachusetts. (Source: Massachusetts Octagon House Inventory).|Caption on image: Octagon house off old Rte. 2 (general)|Binder Number 4. Pocket Number: 1|Format: 35mm col. slide|Slide created date: This date is approximate. 1970

row.Title: First Parish Church, view of façade, Berlin, Massachusetts.
row.Creator: Floyd, Margaret Henderson.
row.Description: The First Parish Church was built in 1826. Located in Berlin Massachusetts and an example of Federal architecture. It also has a three-stage tower and is equipped with a bell. (Source: First Parish Church of Berlin website).|Caption on image: First Parish Church (3) Façade 1826|Binder Number 4. row.Title: Edward Stanwood House, general view, Brookline, Massachusetts.
row.Creator: Floyd, Margaret Henderson.
row.Description: Exterior view of the Edward Stanwood House located on High Street in Brookline. Designed in 1880 for this editor of the American Youth's Companion. Composed of different materials, stucco, brick, terra cotta and stone, it captures the spirit of the Queen Anne Revival which forms a large component of Brookline's architectural history. (Source: Brookline Village Walking Tours website).|Caption on image: Edward Stanwood House (2) Ext. gen view, High St. Walking Tour|Binder Number 4. Pocket Number: 4|Format: 35mm col. slide|Slide created date: This date is approximate. 1970
row.Subject: Architectural practice--Massachusetts--Brookline--History.|Regionalism in architecture--Massachusetts.|Architecture, Queen Anne--Massachusetts--Brookline.

row.Title: Aspinwall area, general view of the Dutch house, Brookline, Massachusetts.
row.Creator: Floyd, Margaret Henderson.
row.Description: Exterior view of the Dutch house facade built in 1892. The Dutch House is a historic house at 20 Netherlands Road in Brookline, Massachusetts. It was built as part of the World's Fair in Chicago or (World's Columbian Exposition) and is one of the only surviving buildings. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1986. (Source: Wikipedia).|Caption on image: Aspinwall Area (2) Dutch House façade Walking Tour 1892|Binder Number 4. Pocket Number: 5|Format: 35mm col. slide|Slide created date: This date is approximate. 1970

row.Title: Longwood area, general view of a Mansard style house on Carlton Street, Brookline, Massachusetts.
row.Creator: Floyd, Margaret Henderson.
row.Description: General exterior view of a mansard style house in the Longwood area of Brookline, Massachusetts. One of several slides taken in this area. Mansard or mansard roof (also called a French roof) is a four-sided gambrel-style hip roof characterized by two slopes on each of its sides with the lower slope, punctured by dormer windows, at a steeper angle than the upper. The roof creates an additional floor of habitable space. (Source: Wikipedia).|Caption on image: Longwood Area (2) Mansard Style House Walking Tour|Binder Number 4. Pocket Number: 14|Format: 35mm col. slide|Slide created date: This date is approximate. 1970

row.Title: Town Green area, general view of Pierce Hall, Brookline, Massachusetts.
row.Creator: Floyd, Margaret Henderson.
row.Description: Originally built in 1824 as a two-story Town House to hold a school, a meeting hall, and town offices.
